Award.AwardTitle: International Workshop on the Nexus of Food, Energy, Water and Soil

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
1649510
Zhuang, Jie

Food production is closely linked to energy consumption, water/soil resources, and ecosystem conditions. This workshop aims to develop an integrative research, education, and industry agenda for securing food production, producing clean energy, protecting water resources, and improving soil productivity while developing economy and social wellbeing. Conference sessions and panel discussions will address important issues from an international perspective.

Specific workshop topics include: (1) Food Security and Safety - The workshop will overview the existing problems and potential risks associated with food production in terms of the demands of food quantity and quality. New methods of characterizing the cycling processes of matter and energy in agroecosystems will be discussed; (2) Energy Efficiency and Impact - Workshop participants will discuss specific technologies and policies that offer the greatest possibility of high efficient utilization of fossil fuels and renewable energy resources including biomass and water. The workshop is expected to create international joint research teams to further investigate these issues from life cycle and multi-dimensional perspectives; (3) Water Efficiency and Recycling - Workshop participants will exchange technologies and perspectives on water-saving agriculture and wastewater utilization. In particular, urban storm water management will be addressed; (4) Soil Productivity and Remediation - The workshop will address the latest approaches to promoting soil fertility and productivity and safe use of contaminated arable lands for food or non-food purposes. A joint team is expected to be establish for developing modeling tools that could predict threshold values of contaminants (especially heavy metals) for ensuring food quality and ecosystem health.

Institution.Name: University of Tennessee Institute of Agriculture

POR.DRECONTENT:
A China-US Workshop on "International Nexus of Food, Energy, Water and Soil (INFEWS)" (also named as "China-US Symposium on Environmental Science and Pollution Control") was held on October 26-29, 2016 in Yixing, Jiangsu Province, China. More than 150 scientists and program leaders (33 from USA, UK and Hong Kong) attended. A total of 72 presentations were made at six sessions and two topical workshops, which covered topics ranging from water and soil pollution to food safety, green energy and graduate education. Seven keynote speeches were made on the opening/closing ceremonies by Prof. Warren Washington (Nationa Center for Atmospheric Research, USA), Prof. Nanqi Ren (Harbin Institute of Technology, China),  and four other distinguished experts. After the conference, ~30 attendees toured research facility and field sites. Three U.S. PhD students and more than 20 Chinese graduate students participated in the scientific exchange activities.

The workshop aimed to facilitate US-China collaboration in developing an integrative research, education, and industry agenda for securing food production, producing clean energy, protecting water resources, and improving soil productivity while developing economy and social wellbeing. Specific objectives were to (1) exchange knowledge of sustainability in food, energy, water and soil systems; (2) create a powerful model for joint PhD and scholar exchange program in environmental research; (3) facilitate development of US-China industry networks for environmental sustainability.

As the first time, the concepts, framework and potentials of INFEWS for environmental sustainability was addressed and discussed between Chinese and the U.S. scientists. The workshop promoted systematic and transformational thinking on environmental sustainability in relation to food production, water security, soil conservation and population growth. As a good result, the workshop motivated establishment of China-US Research Coordination Network of INFEWS and triggered consideration of including food production into an existing, University of Tennessee-based China-US Joint PhD program in environment and energy. In addition, the workshop strengthened connection of academia to industry through China Yixing Industry Park for Environmental Science and Technology, which is home base of near 2,000 environmental companies in China. This connection might lead to true collaboration of the U.S. and Chinese environmental companies.
